qas.question: On which sutras did the Vedanta school focus?
In what time did the Vedanta school become active?
Which is the most developed and well known of the Hindu schools?
How many ways did the Vedantins have of gaining knowledge?
On what was dependent for the choice of methods in gaining knowledge?
What is the least developed Hindu school?
Which sutras did the Vedanta reject?
When did the Vedanta school end?
Which method of gaining knowledge is not included in the Vedanta school?
What are sub-schools not allowed to do with the epistemologies?

context: <b5_0>The <a2_0>Vedānta<a2_0/> school<b5_0/> built upon the teachings of the <a0_0><b6_0>Upanishads and Brahma<b6_0/><a0_0/> Sutras from <b7_0>the <a1_0>first millennium BCE<b7_0/><a1_0/> and is the most developed and well-known of the Hindu schools. The epistemology of the Vedantins included, depending on the <a4_0>sub-school<a4_0/>, <a3_0>five or six methods<a3_0/> as proper and reliable means of gaining any form of knowledge: pratyakṣa (perception), anumāṇa (inference), upamāṇa (comparison and analogy), arthāpatti (postulation, derivation from circumstances), anupalabdi (non-perception, negative/cognitive proof) and <b8_0>śabda<b8_0/> (word, testimony of past or present reliable experts). Each of these have been <b9_0>further categorized<b9_0/> in terms of conditionality, completeness, confidence and possibility of error, by each sub-school of Vedanta.
